items.title: 3d:Â  Hardsurface practice references
items.summary: Collection of various accessories that are perfect hardsurface modelling exercises. Most people problems when it come to modelling complex items are based on inability of observing the item and dividing into smaller parts - objects rarely are uniform, one-piece structures, they are assembled from many…
items.content_html:
Collection of various accessories that are perfect hardsurface modelling exercises. Most people problems when it come to modelling complex items are based on inability of observing the item and dividing into smaller parts - objects rarely are uniform, one-piece structures, they are assembled from many smaller parts - guns, cars, rtv equipment, construction machinery, you name it. By doing few of these items, level by level, you should get the idea how to get from simple item that is assembled from 1-5 objects, to much more complex items that are assemblies of multiple parts.

Starting from simple ones like these:

To middle-level ones like these:

To complicated ones, like these:

Â 

You can get the zip with whole package from my mega upload:Â 

https://mega.nz/file/pRFWWCqK#EA5QZfZG70G6I6jE6kJG9d6cBHcsvU4nQ517PhmujgQ

items.title: MAXSCRIPT: Toggle trackbar / statusbar
items.summary: Maxscript I wrote to salvage these 50 or so pixels on ther bottom area, especially when I'm doing some more devlook oriented tasks, not animating or duplicating / rotating / transforming objects. It'll hide trackbar slider + trackbar then status bar when you click it,…
items.content_html:
Maxscript I wroteÂ  to salvage these 50 or so pixels on ther bottom area, especially when I'm doing some more devlook oriented tasks, not animating or duplicating / rotating / transforming objects. It'll hide trackbar slider + trackbar then status bar when you click it, and after third click, will show them again.

macroScript toggleTrackbarUIÂ 
Â  Â  category:"_Piro_Tools"
Â  Â  internalCategory:"UU: toggleTrackbar"Â 
Â  Â  tooltip:"UV: toggleTrackbar"
Â  Â  ButtonText:"toggleTB"Â 
Â  Â  autoUndoEnabled:false
Â  Â  Icon:#("SchematicView",1)
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  if (trackbar.visible == true) then (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  timeSlider.setVisible (false) -- hide time slider
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  trackbar.visible = false -- hide track bar
Â  Â  Â  Â  ) else (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if (statusPanel.visible == true) then (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  statusPanel.visible = false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ) else (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  timeSlider.setVisible (true) -- show time slider
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  trackbar.visible = true -- show track bar
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  statusPanel.visible = true -- show status panel
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )

As always, you'll find it here:

Â

items.title: Grocery Shopping: T4M Training Glock Pistol
items.summary: Word of caution first. These things are often sold as "self defence tools" - they are not suitable for self defence, unless you want to smack someone with pistol frame itself. Sellers who feed upon unknowing people selling false feeling of safety should really be…
items.content_html:
Word of caution first. These things are often sold as "self defence tools" - they are not suitable for self defence, unless you want to smack someone with pistol frame itself. Sellers who feed upon unknowing people selling false feeling of safety should really be hold accountable for misinforming any potential buyers. However, it is still nice looking piece, and it has some potential for being "training" item.Â 

Due to accidental shopping cart clearing, I've acquired an Umarex TPM 1 RAM T4E Law Enforcement .43 training pistol. While I like to shoot Glock 17, the gun that this training pistol was modelled on, I had no idea what to expect from this weird-market-niche product. Here's a store picture:

Upon receiving the package and taking it out of shipping cardboard box, in sight we have nice plastic casing, not really looking like original Glock one:

With opening of two plastic latches (the one that can break off easily, just being part of the case mold, not separate pieces with hinges), we have whole content presented before us:Â 

While handling the gun, we have a very nice iron sights with orange paint accents at disposal - weird colour choice, but it fits the blue-training frame (That's metal! Probably zn-al though, so don't expect it to be durable) of the gun. It compliments the colour theme well, and is much easier on the eyes than contrast red colour near blue one.

Â 

In front of pistol, under barrel, there's short accessory rail, that will allow you to mount unnecessary ad-dons like lasers and flashlights if you really want to:

On picture above, note the distance slide is moved back - that's the max distance distance it travels, which have its pros and cons:
Pros - less CO2 gas would be wasted after shot for moving that part, as blowback (the movement of slide back and forth, that in real gun would cause ejection of casing when backing, and loading new round when moving forward) here is purely cosmetic, and not required by the way gun operates.
Cons - Blowback would be really low, almost nonexistent. Also, it's not very realistic if we consider it a "training" model, which might cause people to expect slide on real thing to also travel such small distance, potentially risking hurting fingers if they wander not where they should be. That's enough about complains about that, there's more on the way anyway. Picture below shows what we see when slide is locked in back position - this isn't a "bullet chamber", nor part of barrel:

Â 

This is top part of magazine, and that means whole shooting mechanism is done by magazine itself - gas valve, release button, seals, everything is contained in magazine itself - that means magazines will be very expensive, and technically you can shoot the bullet without the gun, just releasing gas manually without gun itself (not recommended). Here's magazine itself:

That concludes visual tour around the item. This article will be updated when I have time and peace to shoot myself with it some target board at 10m to tell more about its accuracy, but I don't expect lot from smooth barrel and CO2 as propellant.

Â 

Â

items.title: MAXSCRIPT: Proportional Reference Plane
items.summary: Script I often use while setting up reference planes from simple pictures: 1. Make plane object (any size/proportions). 2. Drag and drop image from folder to plane. 3. Select plane with now applied texture. 3. Click on button/toolbar/quad you assigned script to. 4. Plane width/height…
items.content_html:
Script I often use while setting up reference planes from simple pictures:
1. Make plane object (any size/proportions).
2. Drag and drop image from folder to plane.
3. Select plane with now applied texture.
3. Click on button/toolbar/quad you assigned script to.
4. Plane width/height in max units is set according image width / height in pixels. Just scale the plane afterwards to desired size.

macroScript proportionalRefPlaneÂ 
Â  Â  category:"_Piro_Tools"Â 
Â  Â  tooltip:"UI: proportionalRefPlane"Â 
Â  Â  buttontext:"UI: proportionalRefPlane"
(
Â  Â  clearlistener()
Â  Â  planeL = 0
Â  Â  planeW = 0
Â  Â  planeName = "testref"
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  function isSelectedObjectPlane =Â 
(
Â  Â  -- Get the currently selected object
Â  Â  local selectedObj = selection[1]
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Check if the selected object is a plane object
Â  Â  if (classof selectedObj == Plane) then
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  return true -- The selected object is a plane object
Â  Â  )
Â  Â  else
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  return false -- The selected object is not a plane object
Â  Â  )
)
Â  Â Â 
function selectObjectWithLargestBoundingBox =
(
Â  Â  local maxBBSize = 0 -- Initialize the maximum bounding box size to 0
Â  Â  local objWithMaxBB -- Initialize the object with the largest bounding box to undefined
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  for obj in objects do -- Iterate through all objects in the scene
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  local objBB = obj.boundingBox
Â  Â  Â  Â  local objBBSize = objBB.max - objBB.min
Â  Â  Â  Â  local objBBDiagonal = length objBBSize
Â  Â  Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  Â  Â  if objBBDiagonal > maxBBSize do -- Check if this object has a larger bounding box than the previous largest
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  maxBBSize = objBBDiagonal
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  objWithMaxBB = obj
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  return objWithMaxBB -- Select the object with the largest bounding box
)

--selectObjectWithLargestBoundingBox() -- Call the function to select the object with the largest bounding box


fn scaleToFit objToScale refObj =Â 
(
Â  Â  -- Get the bounding boxes of both objects
Â  Â  local objBB = (nodeTransformBoundingBox objToScale).minmax
Â  Â  local refBB = (nodeTransformBoundingBox refObj).minmax
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Get the sizes of the objects' bounding boxes along each axis
Â  Â  local objSize = objBB[2] - objBB[1]
Â  Â  local refSize = refBB[2] - refBB[1]
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Calculate the ratio of sizes along each axis
Â  Â  local scaleFactor = [1,1,1]
Â  Â  for i = 1 to 3 do (
Â  Â  Â  Â  if refSize[i] != 0 do scaleFactor[i] = objSize[i] / refSize[i]
Â  Â  )
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Scale the object using the calculated scale factor
Â  Â  objToScale.scale = objToScale.scale * scaleFactor
)



function getBitmapNameOnly bitmapPath =Â 
(
Â  Â  nameOnly = ""
Â  Â  -- Get the filename from the bitmap path
Â  Â  local fileName = getFilenameFile bitmapPath
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Remove the extension from the filename
Â  Â  --local nameOnly = filterString fileName ".*" ""
Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  -- Return just the name of the file without the path or extension
Â  Â  return fileName
)

Â  Â  fn GetBitmapTextures theObjects =
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  texMaps = #()
Â  Â  Â  Â  for obj in theObjects do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  join texMaps (getClassInstances bitmapTexture target:obj asTrackViewPick:off)
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  makeUniqueArray texMaps
Â  Â  )
Â  Â  texMaps = (GetBitmapTextures selection)
Â  Â  for texMap in texMaps doÂ 
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  testTexture = bitmaptexture filename:texMap.filename
Â  Â  Â  Â  print (texMap.filename)
Â  Â  Â  Â  print (testTexture.Bitmap.height as string +"px H x "+testTexture.Bitmap.width as string +"px W")
Â  Â  Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  Â  Â  if isSelectedObjectPlane() then
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  selection[1].length = testTexture.Bitmap.height
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  selection[1].width = testTexture.Bitmap.width
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  selection[1].name = getBitmapNameOnly(texMap.filename)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  print ("Reference plane changed.")
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  --testObj = selectObjectWithLargestBoundingBox()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  --scaleToFit selection[1] testObj
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â Â 
Â  Â  )
Â  Â Â 

Â  Â  Â  Â  OK
Â  Â Â 
)

Â 

Â

items.title: MAXSCRIPT: quickBridge - One bridge ( connect too) to rule them all.
items.summary: Very short script I've wrote that will detect which sub-selection of editable poly you are in, and will try to connect the selected objects - so you can bind it under one key instead of four: If you're in vertex sub-selection, it'll connect selected verticles.
items.content_html:
Very short script I've wrote that will detect which sub-selection of editable poly you are in, and will try to connect the selected objects - so you can bind it under one key instead of four:

If you're in vertex sub-selection, it'll connect selected verticles.
If you're in edge sub-selection, it'll bridge selected edges.
If you're in border sub-selection, it'll cap selected border.
If you're in face sub-selection, it'll bridge selected faces.

Code for script:
macroScript quickBridgeÂ 
Â  Â  category:"_Piro_Tools"Â 
Â  Â  tooltip:"MESH: quickBridge"Â 
Â  Â  buttontext:"MESH: quickBridge"
(
Â  Â  if (classof (modPanel.getCurrentObject()) == Editable_Poly) then
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  case subObjectLevel of
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  1: ($.EditablePoly.ConnectVertices())
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  2: ($.EditablePoly.Bridge())
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  3: ($.EditablePoly.capHoles #Edge)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  4: (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  $.bridgeSelected = 1
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  $.EditablePoly.Bridge()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â )
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )
Â  Â  else if (classof (modPanel.getCurrentObject()) == Edit_Poly) then
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  case subObjectLevel of
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  1: ($.modifiers[#Edit_Poly].ButtonOp #ConnectVertices)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  2: ($.modifiers[#Edit_Poly].ButtonOp #BridgeEdge)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  3: ($.modifiers[#Edit_Poly].ButtonOp #Cap)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  4: ($.modifiers[#Edit_Poly].ButtonOp #BridgePolygon)
Â  Â  Â  Â  ) Â  Â 
Â  Â  )
)

After evaluating it in maxscript editor / saving it as .ms and drag-n-dropping on max, You'll find "MESH: quickBridge" macro under "_Piro_Tools" category in customisation menu. Enjoy

quick edit - now works on both Editable_Poly and Edit_Poly modifier!

Btw, thanks for GPT4 for streamlining this script into nice compact version.

items.title: Collection of peculiar portable devices, part 1
items.summary: I had to share a gallery of weird devices with few people in short period of time, so making an easily findable (for me) place for it seemed like good excuse for a post. Gallery is split to groups per 100 images, so be sure…
items.content_html:
I had to share a gallery of weird devices with few people in short period of time, so making an easily findable (for me) place for it seemed like good excuse for a post.

Gallery is split to groups per 100 images, so be sure to check all of them, otherwise it'll only loop through first 100 instead of all 400 pictures.

I have no information about these devices, you're free to reverse image search them, and put comments with models/information about them under this post, I'll update them when I have time.

items.title: MAXSCRIPT: InsetFix Smoothgroup Modifier
items.summary: Note: This script isn't mine, but its made by very talented Vojtech Cada - I'm reposting it here mostly for myself, so I wont lose it, and to show some viewers. Original link it was grabbed from is: http://www.scriptspot.com/3ds-max/scripts/insetfix-modifier Some time ago I've included InsetFix…
items.content_html:
Note: This script isn't mine, but its made by very talented Vojtech Cada - I'm reposting it here mostly for myself, so I wont lose it, and to show some viewers. Original link it was grabbed from is: http://www.scriptspot.com/3ds-max/scripts/insetfix-modifier

Some time ago I've included InsetFix to my workflow, and it speeds up modelling by a lot. See the difference between build-in 3ds max inset (left), applied per-smoothgroup, and InsetFix (right):

As you can see, after mesh have correctly set smoothgroups, it automatically creates good base topology for applying subdivision, with corners protected by edges.

Code for script, in case you cant download it from scriptspot anymore - save it as InsetFix.ms, put in startup folder (or execute manually every time), and you'll find InsetFix on modifier list:

plugin simpleMeshMod insetSGFix
Â  Â  name:"InsetSGFix"
Â  Â  classID:#(0xc4e63a8, 0x2a9ccb40)
-- Â  Â author:"Vojtech Cada"
(
Â  Â  parameters main rollout:params
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  inset type:#worldUnits default:0 ui:spnInset
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  rollout params "Parameters"
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  spinner spnInset "Inset: " type:#worldUnits range:[1e-9, 1e9, 0]
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  local faceIndex

Â  Â  fn getFaceEdge face edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  (face - 1) * 3 + edge

Â  Â  fn getFaceVert face index =
Â  Â  Â  Â  int (getFace mesh face)[index]

Â  Â  fn getReverseEdge edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  ((meshop.getEdgesReverseEdge mesh edge) as array)[1]

Â  Â  fn getProjectedInset edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.getVert mesh edge.insetVertA - edge.vertAPos

Â  Â  struct orientedEdge
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  -- vert indices:
Â  Â  Â  Â  vertA, vertAPos, insetVertA, innerVertA = vertA, innerInsetVertA,
Â  Â  Â  Â  vertB, vertBPos, insetVertB, innerVertB = vertB, innerInsetVertB,

Â  Â  Â  Â  face, -- the face that the edge belongs to
Â  Â  Â  Â  vertAFaceIndex, -- index of vertA in the face
Â  Â  Â  Â  vertBFaceIndex, -- index of vertB in the face

Â  Â  Â  Â  isEdgeCornerAReflex = false, innerOffsetA,
Â  Â  Â  Â  isEdgeCornerBReflex = false, innerOffsetB,

Â  Â  Â  Â  smoothGroup,
Â  Â  Â  Â  active = true, -- when active, no faces were created for this edge yet
Â  Â  Â  Â  divided = false,
Â  Â  Â  Â  dir = normalize (vertBPos - vertAPos), -- edge direction
Â  Â  Â  Â  index = (face - 1) * 3 + vertAFaceIndex, -- edge index

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn getInsetVert vertFaceIndex =
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  getFaceVert face vertFaceIndex,

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn getEdgeDiv offset =
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  offset / distance (meshop.getVert mesh insetVertA) \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (meshop.getVert mesh insetVertB),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn insertCornerVertA div =
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.divideEdge mesh index (getEdgeDiv div) fixNeighbors:false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  innerInsetVertA = mesh.numVerts
Â  Â  Â  Â  ),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn insertCornerVertB div =
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.divideEdge mesh index (1 - getEdgeDiv div) fixNeighbors:false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  innerInsetVertB = mesh.numVerts
Â  Â  Â  Â  ),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn initInsetVerts =
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  innerInsetVertA = insetVertA = getInsetVert vertAFaceIndex
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  innerInsetVertB = insetVertB = getInsetVert vertBFaceIndex
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  struct edgePair
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  smoothGroup,

Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeA, edgeReverseA,
Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeB, edgeReverseB,

Â  Â  Â  Â  innerEdgeA = getReverseEdge edgeA.index,
Â  Â  Â  Â  innerEdgeB = getReverseEdge edgeB.index,

Â  Â  Â  Â  innerOffset = dot edgeA.dir (getProjectedInset edgeA),
Â  Â  Â  Â  isAngleReflex = innerOffset < 0,
Â  Â  Â  Â  isEdgeCornerReflex,

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn insertCornerVertA = edgeA.insertCornerVertA (inset - innerOffset),
Â  Â  Â  Â  fn insertCornerVertB = edgeB.insertCornerVertB (inset - innerOffset),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn insertCornerVerts edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local divA = edge.getEdgeDiv (inset - edge.innerOffsetA)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local divB = edge.getEdgeDiv (inset - edge.innerOffsetB)

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.divideEdge mesh edge.index divA fixNeighbors:false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.divideEdge mesh edge.index (1 - divB / (1 - divA)) fixNeighbors:false

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edge.innerInsetVertB = mesh.numVerts
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edge.innerInsetVertA = edge.innerInsetVertB - 1Â 
Â  Â  Â  Â  ),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn divideEdge edge isEdgeCornerReflex insertCornerVert =
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if isEdgeCornerReflex then
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if not edge.divided do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  insertCornerVerts edge
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edge.divided = true
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  else insertCornerVert(),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn divideEdgeA = divideEdge edgeA edgeA.isEdgeCornerBReflex insertCornerVertA,
Â  Â  Â  Â  fn divideEdgeB = divideEdge edgeB edgeB.isEdgeCornerAReflex insertCornerVertB,

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn addCornerFaces =
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if isAngleReflex then
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.createPolygon mesh #(edgeA.vertA, edgeA.innerVertA, edgeA.innerInsetVertA, edgeA.insetVertA)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.createPolygon mesh #(edgeB.innerVertB, edgeB.vertB, edgeB.insetVertB, edgeB.innerInsetVertB)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceIndex += 4
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  #{getFaceEdge (faceIndex - 3) 1, getFaceEdge (faceIndex - 1) 2}
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  else
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.createPolygon mesh #(edgeA.vertA, edgeA.innerVertA, edgeA.insetVertA, edgeB.innerVertB)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceIndex += 2
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  #{getFaceEdge (faceIndex - 1) 1, getFaceEdge (faceIndex) 3}
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ),

Â  Â  Â  Â  fn addJointQuads =
Â  Â  Â  Â  ((
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if not edgeA.active then #{} else
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.createPolygon mesh #(edgeA.innerVertA, edgeA.innerVertB, edgeA.innerInsetVertB, edgeA.innerInsetVertA)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceIndex += 2
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  #{getFaceEdge (faceIndex - 1) 1}
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )) + (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if not edgeB.active then #{} else
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.createPolygon mesh #(edgeB.innerInsetVertA, edgeB.innerVertA, edgeB.innerVertB, edgeB.innerInsetVertB)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceIndex += 2
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  #{getFaceEdge (faceIndex - 1) 2}
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ))
Â  Â  Â  Â  ),

Â  Â  Â  Â  on create do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeA.isEdgeCornerAReflex = edgeB.isEdgeCornerBReflex = isAngleReflex
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeA.innerOffsetA = edgeB.innerOffsetB = innerOffset
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  struct corner
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  edges,
Â  Â  Â  Â  reverseEdges,
Â  Â  Â  Â  oppositeEdges = #(),
Â  Â  Â  Â  edgePairs,

Â  Â  Â  Â  on create do edgePairs =
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for i = 1 to edges.count collect
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local edgeA = edges[i]
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local edgeB = reverseEdges[i]
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeA.initInsetVerts()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edgeB.initInsetVerts()

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  edgePair smoothGroup:edgeA.smoothGroup edgeA:edgeA edgeB:edgeB \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â edgeReverseA:(for edge in reverseEdges where edge.vertA == edgeA.vertB do exit with edge) \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â edgeReverseB:(for edge in edges where edge.vertB == edgeB.vertA do exit with edge)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  fn comparevertA i1 i2 =
Â  Â  Â  Â  if i1.vertA == i2.vertA then
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  i1.smoothGroup - i2.smoothGroup
Â  Â  Â  Â  else i1.vertA - i2.vertA

Â  Â  fn comparevertB i1 i2 =
Â  Â  Â  Â  if i1.vertB == i2.vertB then
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  i1.smoothGroup - i2.smoothGroup
Â  Â  Â  Â  else i1.vertB - i2.vertB

Â  Â  fn wrapFaceIndex index =
Â  Â  Â  Â  int(mod (index - 1) 3) + 1

Â  Â  fn getEdgeFace edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  if edge == undefined then 0 else (edge - 1) / 3 + 1

Â  Â  fn getReverseFace edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  getEdgeFace (getReverseEdge edge)

Â  Â  fn getOppositeFace face edge =
Â  Â  Â  Â  getReverseFace (getFaceEdge face edge)

Â  Â  fn makeEdge index face faceVerts smoothGroup =
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  local vertA = int faceVerts[index]
Â  Â  Â  Â  local vertB = int faceVerts[wrapFaceIndex (index + 1)]

Â  Â  Â  Â  orientedEdge vertA:vertA vertAPos:(meshop.getVert mesh vertA) \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â vertB:vertB vertBPos:(meshop.getVert mesh vertB) \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â vertAFaceIndex:index vertBFaceIndex:(wrapFaceIndex (index + 1)) \
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â face:face smoothGroup:smoothGroup
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  fn getSGElements mesh =
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  local vertCount = mesh.numVerts
Â  Â  Â  Â  local done = #{}, faces = mesh.faces as bitArray -- all the mesh face indices, will be eliminated one by one
Â  Â  Â  Â  local facesByVert = for v = 1 to vertCount collect #() -- list of faces sharing the individual verts, filled in the next step:

Â  Â  Â  Â  for face in faces do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local faceVerts = getFace mesh face
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append facesByVert[faceVerts[1]] face
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append facesByVert[faceVerts[2]] face
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append facesByVert[faceVerts[3]] face
Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  -- collect and return element data:
Â  Â  Â  Â  for face in faces collect
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local i = 0 -- dynamic index, incremented in while loop, tries to get next appended face
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local element = #(face) -- get one of the remaining faces
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local border = #() -- SG border verts
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local elementSG = getFaceSmoothGroup mesh face -- get its SG

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- while there's still at least one other face appended in the previous while iteration:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  while (local f = element[i += 1]) != undefined do if faces[f] /* and we haven't seen that face before */ do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faces[f] = false -- remove that face from candidate pool
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append done f -- could be merged with faces check, though it reads easier this way
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local faceVerts = getFace mesh f -- get its three verts
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local vertBuffer = 0 -- face verts sharing different SG encoded as bits
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local faceBuffer = #{} -- faces across the SG border

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for v = 1 to 3 do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local vert = int(faceVerts[v]) -- indexed face vertex

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- for faces sharing the given vert:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for vertFace in facesByVert[vert] do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if getFaceSmoothGroup mesh vertFace == elementSG then -- it's the same SG
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if not done[vertFace] do -- we haven't seen it before
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append element vertFace -- append it to the current element
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append done vertFace -- append to the list of previously appended faces
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  else -- doesn't share the same SG
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  vertBuffer = bit.set vertBuffer v true -- add the vertex to SG border verts buffer
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceBuffer[vertFace] = true -- add the face to border face buffer
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  vertFace -- collect it with the rest of remaining facesByVert
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  case vertBuffer of
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  3: if (fInv = getOppositeFace f 1) == 0 or faceBuffer[fInv] doÂ 
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append border (makeEdge 1 f faceVerts elementSG) -- verts 1 and 2
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  6: if (fInv = getOppositeFace f 2) == 0 or faceBuffer[fInv] do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append border (makeEdge 2 f faceVerts elementSG) -- verts 2 and 3
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  5: if (fInv = getOppositeFace f 3) == 0 or faceBuffer[fInv] do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append border (makeEdge 3 f faceVerts elementSG) -- verts 1 and 3
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  7: for ei = 1 to 3 where (fInv = getOppositeFace f ei) == 0 or faceBuffer[fInv] do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append border (makeEdge ei f faceVerts elementSG) -- verts 1, 2, 3
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â -- collect a tuple (faces with the same SG, SG border edges):
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  dataPair faces:(element as bitArray) border:border
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  fn cornersFromSortedBorder border type: =
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  local i = 1, edgeCount = border.count
Â  Â  Â  Â  local corners = #()

Â  Â  Â  Â  while i < edgeCount do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local vert = getProperty border[i] type
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local corner = #()

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- append one and continue getting while the ones following share the same index:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  do append corner border[i]
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  while i < edgeCount and getProperty border[i += 1] type == vert

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  append corners corner
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  return corners
Â  Â  )

Â  Â  on modifyMesh do
Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  local border = #(), selectedEdges = #(), facesToDelete = #{}
Â  Â  Â  Â  local faceCount = mesh.numFaces
Â  Â  Â  Â  local elements = getSGElements mesh

Â  Â  Â  Â  for element in elements do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshOp.extrudeFaces mesh element.faces 0 -inset
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  join border element.border
Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  if mesh.numFaces > faceCount do
Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- select new faces:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local selectedFaces = setFaceSelection mesh #{faceCount + 1 .. mesh.numFaces} as array

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- collect new edges for selection:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local edge = (selectedFaces[1] - 1) * 3 + 1
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local selectedEdges = #{edge}
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for f = 3 to selectedFaces.count by 2 do append selectedEdges (edge += 6)

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- sort all the border verts by the first edge vertex index:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  qSort border comparevertA
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local corners = cornersFromSortedBorder border type:#vertA

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- sort all the border verts by the second edge vertex index:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  qSort border comparevertB
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local reverseCorners = cornersFromSortedBorder border type:#vertB

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- corners sharing more than two smoothing groups:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local multiCorners = for c = 1 to corners.count where corners[c].count > 2 collect
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  corner edges:corners[c] reverseEdges:reverseCorners[c]

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- get corner support points count:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local cornerPtsCount = 0
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for corner in multiCorners do cornerPtsCount += corner.edges.count

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- add corner support points:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  local vertCount = mesh.numVerts
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  setNumVerts mesh (vertCount + cornerPtsCount) true

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- set and add vertices:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for corner in multiCorners do for pair in corner.edgePairs do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  setVert mesh (vertCount += 1) (pair.edgeA.vertAPos + inset * pair.edgeA.dir)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  pair.edgeA.innerVertA = pair.edgeReverseA.innerVertB = vertCount

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if pair.isAngleReflex do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  pair.divideEdgeA()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  pair.divideEdgeB()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  faceIndex = mesh.numFaces

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- add polygons:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  for corner in multiCorners do for pair in corner.edgePairs do
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  join facesToDelete (meshop.getPolysUsingEdge mesh pair.innerEdgeA)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  join facesToDelete (meshop.getPolysUsingEdge mesh pair.innerEdgeB)

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  selectedEdges += pair.addCornerFaces()
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  selectedEdges += pair.addJointQuads()

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  -- mark all used edges inactive:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  pair.edgeA.active = false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  pair.edgeB.active = false
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  )

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  setEdgeSelection mesh selectedEdges
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  meshop.deleteFaces mesh facesToDelete delIsoVerts:false
Â  Â  Â  Â  )
Â  Â  )
)

Â 

Â 

Â

items.title: OK BOOMER 3D Workflow, it works - 2023 EDITION
items.summary: Old version can be found here: OK BOOMER, HOW IT WORKS This is an update to my previous workflow describing article, with few updates to tools/plugins I use. It is still very 3ds max centric, but some procedures can be applied to Maya or Blender…
items.content_html:
Old version can be found here: OK BOOMER, HOW IT WORKS

This is an update to my previous workflow describing article, with few updates to tools/plugins I use. It is still very 3ds max centric, but some procedures can be applied to Maya or Blender along the way.

First, software and plugins I mostly use for authoring models (not everything obviously, but major players that are installed on every computer I ever worked on):

Pureref - Pureref download page
3ds Max (2023 for now) - Whats new - Autodesk Max 2023
Marmoset Toolbag 3Â  - Marmoset Toolbag Website - (4 will do as long it allows baking meshes)
Substance Painter - Substance Painter Steam version with lifetime licence
Textools - Textools for 3ds max
InsetFix Modifier - InsetFix maxscript download - greatly helps with sub-d workflow.
UVPacker - UVPacker for max - you don't really need paid version.

In this post I'll focus on modelling only, and continue with baking / texturing techniques in later posts.
Biggest change from my workflow post from years ago is that I've got rid of UVLayout, as UVPacker allows same if not better packing results, and incorporating InsetFix permanently to by workflow.

First step, even before opening 3DS max, Is to gather references - depending on thing you want to model, simple google image search can be enough for the job, sometimes its good to own some books about certain topic or visit museum with a camera. Or buy the gun you want to model, but that's extreme.
Favorite software to group references for me is Pureref, as it allows for automatic and manual grouping of images, and show them in one window in form of a big gallery of everything, with intuitive zooming and panning, This is how pureref looked like for my LR300 (check the model itself here: Artstation page ) project:

My lowpoly models are still created 100% in 3DS Max, unless I really want to use Cad (moi3d / fusion360, but thats more for concepting/designing things rather than pure modelling). After gathering references, I start blockout phase, sometimes used interchangeable with "basemesh" - depending how much time there is, and if I forget its blockout and start putting details too soon, but still not paying attention to clean topology - this is mostly to get proportions and shapes right. I still try to keep most of polygons as quads if possible, as it'll help me optimise/retopologise later.

With blockout done, I do proper basemesh based on it - It has defined all the details I'd like to see on LP (Lowpoly) geometry, and proportions that match the references, and after finishing it, duplicate it, hide source, and start working on HP (Highpoly). Personally I prefer sub-d modelling exclusively, currently popular workflows like to include zbrush/dynamesh/proboolean workflow, it's ok when the time is tight and you need to quickly have some results. However, it teaches practically nothing about controlling topology and flow of the geometry, so a good practice is to use sub-d whenever you can, and only half-ass meshes in zbrush when you're in a big hurry and client don't care.

Now that half of the people got offended and stopped reading, the HP I end up with have all the details on geometry, with the exceptions like diamond patterns on grips or fabric weave that can be easily made on texture itself. I do model sometimes braided cables / more complex diamond patterns when the surface they're on is curved, but its usually pain.

With HP done, I go back to my basemesh, that now should overlap with the finished high poly pretty tight. Duplicating it, this will be my low-poly mesh. Im deleting uneccessary edges / division, making the basemesh truly lowpoly, yet detailed enough to bake properly (rules for certain types of objects still apply - where to put denser geo, what chamfer and what not, depending on where the camera looks, et cetera). Now the magical part that streamlines unwrapping by 80% of time. I set up automatic smoothgroups by 33-45 degrees, having most if not all hard edges well defined on low poly, Then I apply unwrap UVW modifier, and use one nifty function - UV chunks by smoothgroups, that creates UV islands based off your smoothgroups. Only thing you need to manually cut are cylinders, that need to be cut on one edge to unwrap properly. After all the pieces are done, I use quick peel, relax, and have quite good, relaxed UVs.

Now, with your model unwrapped, time to make neccessary tweaks to UV proportions before packing:
1. Adjusting UV scale according to how close parts of mesh are to player - If its a gun, then you want iron sights and receiver to have more texels (more uv space /pixels ) than for example interior of barrel.
2. Scaling up smaller elements like bolts/nuts/pins/buttons/labels that will have text on it, so they don't get super-blurry (You can use my script for quick scaling along U/V axes)
3. Rotating most elements in one direction, even if you texture in substance painter, its still good to maintain some edgeflow with uv space, just for texturing sake. Textools "Sort" helps a lot doing that, otherwise use checker with directions marked on top of it in some way.

Now, with all parts aligned and scaled the way you want, apply UVPacker modifier on top of your mesh, and set it like that, so it doesnt try to rotate your aligned UV chunks:

After packing, you'll get niftly packed UV map, similar to this:

All whats left is to make sure our smoothgroups and uv chunks are syncronised, run this:

And your model is ready to be exported for baking.

Look out for post about bakes, in the meantime, check the general baking quide and troubleshooting here:

Getting best normalmap bakes

Â

items.title: TS100 Printable durable case - now with 100% more cyber!
items.summary: I've got linked this by a friend: https://www.printables.com/model/345083-rugged-multipart-pinecilts100ts80-case-v2 And while it seem like a nice upgrade from my previous holding box for ts100, I've quickly realised it have few features I dislike. When I design things, I want them to be as easily printed as…
items.content_html:
I've got linked this by a friend:

https://www.printables.com/model/345083-rugged-multipart-pinecilts100ts80-case-v2

And while it seem like a nice upgrade from my previous holding box for ts100, I've quickly realised it have few features I dislike.

When I design things, I want them to be as easily printed as possible, and modular as possible, and allow lot of customisation from the start. I have Prusa 3D, but without multi-material addon, so only swapping filament on the layer change made sense (And I don't really like purge block method, seems wasteful). Second, I want latches to be easily replacable, and I dont like torque between bigger parts on hinges. Latches should be interchangeable with hinges as well, in case I need a box that is openable completely, with removal of top piece. Second, I dont really need/want/can delegate time to measure every piece of equipment I have, so I'd like to use inserts from already estabilished project, with as minimum changes as possible. And to top all of above, I like certain asthetics, which is mix of utilitarism and cyberpunk styles.

Having this in mind, on the span of 3 days, new version was designed and printed. Some 3ds max shots:

And after few tries on the latches/hinges (I REALLY wanted a subtle dual-tone touch to them), and editing already-done insert with item compartments, I've got final product, that I'm extremely happy with:

Â 

At some point I'll share finished design, probably after I clean it up a bit and make more generic case-design, as I'm convinced that this design is easier to print, and have much stronger structural integrity, with every hinge base/fin thickened, as well few less noticeable changes, mainly to angles as well printable bed surface areas.Â
